Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned basics of Organic Chemistry like mechanisms and reagents of common reactions in a very organized working environment.

I learned a lot about chemistry in general. All the things in gen chem and within the beginning portion of the class really build upon each other in a really cool way. The further this class goes, the more it builds, so it is important not to fall behind. Everything from pKa, functional groups, ions comes into play. Even though it's hard, the material felt very rewarding to practice, learn, and study, because it made more sense as you spent more time on it.
I expected to perform terribly in organic chemistry.  All of my friends talked about how hard the class was, but the professor taught the content in a manner that I was able to understand.
a super number of reactions
We did a lot of understanding why certain mechanisms should make sense at first, but towards the end, it felt like we just rushed though lots of mechanisms.
Good introduction to organic chemistry
Learned a lot.
Reaction mechanisms and the reasons for why they are the way they are
This course is a good introduction to organic chemistry and relies heavily on atomic theory and stereochemistry in the first half while putting an emphasis on mechanisms in the second half.
You learn how to predict reactions and understand their mechanisms.
I got a good foundation in the principles of organic chemistry. A lot of the skills I learned feel like puzzle-solving, which I liked.
I learned a lot of practical information about chemistry and gained a solid grasp of many mechanisms and processes.

Orgo 1 was great! It covers a great deal of content, including quantum mechanics, addition reactions, elimination and substitution, stereochemistry, and alcohol/ether/epoxide corporations. All of the content felt relevant and made me appreciate a lot of other subjects, like bio and biochem, a lot more. By the end, you feel confident in your skills for basic synthesis and reactions, and can even see molecules in 3D effortlessly!
Good introduction to organic chemistry. Great also for biochemical applications. Pretty enjoyable class.
Mostly, I fulfilled a requirement. Though I enjoyed organic chemistry at times, by the end I felt like I was drowning in material.
You pretty much just learn a million mechanisms. The quizzes and exams are very difficult.
Knowledge of organic molecules, organic reactions, stereochemistry
I learned a great deal about the basis of organic chemistry and some introductory reactions/mechanisms.

My knowledge of organic reactions and stereochemistry and my ability to solve organic chemistry problems improved during this course. It was helpful in that my approach to problem-solving had to change to be more critical and synthesize material from many parts of the course.
A pretty good understanding of the foundations of Organic Chemistry.
Organic chem.

I gained a plethora of knowledge in dealing with concepts of organic chemistry. Honestly, in going back and studying for the final, I was truly impressed and amazed at the breadth of information we covered and understood well.

I learned a lot about the various specific chemical reactions as well as generally understanding how to think through mechanism and understand broader chemical concepts that make reactions make sense.
This was a very comprehensive and understandable introduction to organic chemistry and the chemical mechanisms involved in the creation and manipulation of organic molecules.

Orgo I really focuses on reactions in organic chemistry, especially reactions with alkenes. At the end of the semester I was able to predict major organic products formed when different solvents were added to a starting material, and the complete reaction mechanisms for all these reactions. I learned a lot about visualizing organic molecules in 3D in my head, and understanding stereochemistry and it's implications. Orgo I really wasn't as bad as everyone says it is, you just have to stay on top of the "optional" homework and show up to lecture.
I learned very many necessarily skills in organic chemistry
I learned many creative ways to study.
I learned about the mechanisms of many chemical reactions and creative ways to approach synthesis questions.
Theres a lot of memorization required in this class as the material builds up over time, so its especially important to be organized and stay on top of the material to do well in the class.
Lots of organic chemistry intuition.
I've never had organic chemistry before, so this introduction was thorough and helpful in terms of course content.
I was absolutely terrified of organic chemistry going into this class, but surprisingly, orgo with Professor Ellman ended up being my favorite class this semester.
Great intro to organic chemistry
I learned a lot about reactions and how to think logically about how they may occur.

This course highly improved my studying skills.  It was not a course you can take without having a good work ethic.  It also improved my abilities in chemistry and gave me knowledge on common organic reactions.
I learned how to push arrows and memorize reactions!

I learned to understand reaction mechanisms and developed yhe skill to analyze the process by which organic reactions occur. I gained a deeper understanding of organic chemistry and thew basic ideas behind it.
I learned about different chemical reactions and general trends in the periodic table.
basic organic chemistry skills
This course helped me see the connection that chemistry has with biology and physics
A lot about orgo! So many reactions and their mechanisms, etc.
A great deal about organic chemistry and chemical reactivity.
Organic chemistry
I learned about basic organic chemistry, and problem solving
I gained a basic idea of organic chemistry reactions and mechanisms.
I learned so much about organic chemistry and how reaction happen.
Critical thinking
Typical first semester orgo

I fell in love with Organic Chemistry. I learned the mechanisms of the basic organic chemistry reactions, and, most importantly, I learned the theories behind it so that studying for tests was not pure memorization.
I definitely learned a lot about organic chemistry, all new material compared to AP chem! You'll learn a lot about the basics and how to think spatially in 3 dimensions.

I developed a general understanding of many of the basic principles of organic chemistry. Since organic chemistry is a cumulative subject, I was able to build on knowledge that I learned in the beginning of the semester to understand the more challenging concepts towards the end of the semester.
I learned how to apply concepts learned throughout the semester to help me understand more complicated reactions learned later on.
I have a better understanding of chemistry in general and learned new methods for expressing chemical concepts including modeling and drawing. I learned how to synthesize a carbene.
I learned a lot of the pathways of organic reactions and became very familiar with what will occur in certain conditions with given starting materials and reagents.
the principles of organic chem
I learned concepts in organic chemistry and reactions
I learned a ton of organic chemistry in this course. It was extremely interesting and will be helpful in my career in the future.
A good overview of organic chemistry and problem solving skills

I was a little scared to take this course in the beginning, because I learned a little bit of intro orgo in CHEM 163 and I had a really rough time. But Prof. Ellman did such a great job in CHEM 220 that my initial fear was completely irrelevant.
Not only did I learn organic reactions and their mechanisms and stereochemistry, but I really learned why those reactions occurred (the chemical principles behind each reaction). There were some memorizations required, but I think this class made it as principle-based as possible.
Learned basic organic chemistry including alkenes, alkanes, ketones, and epoxides, and their reactivities.
I learned about the basics of organic chemistry.
I learned the basic principles of organic chemistry and how they apply to everyday life. I learned basic reactions and why certain reactions take place more than others depending on the situation.
How to push arrows around, understand what reagents produce which chemical reaction, and, most EXCITING of all, stereochemistry (this will end you lol).
This course really focused on trends and big ideas in Organic Chemistry.
You will learn the basics of reactions and their mechanisms. I thought it was useful, but definitely heavy on wrote skills versus intuition and critical thinking.

I learned organic chemistry concepts, including naming, reactions, and stereochemistry. In doing so, I learned how to spatially visualize compounds and their reactions, as well as various paths a chemist could take to synthesize the same compound.
Organic chemistry!! Basics, curved arrow notation for a ton of different reactions, good overview of basic mechanisms and applications in a broad range of reactions.

Mechanism of organic reactions. Learning material by small chuns. Study with friends and do the pre-reading and exercises and practice tests otherwise this was a really hard class that requires a lot of prep and memorization.

I learned about fundamental concepts in organic chemistry, including types of isomers, stereochemistry, chirality, reactions of alkenes, reactions of alkyl halides, reactions of alcohols, and reactions of ethers. We learned about how to solve synthesis problems.
Nothing that I particularly care about if I'm being honest. I'm just pre med and had to do this.
The mechanisms behind organic chemistry reactions.
I learned a comprehensive introduction of Organic Chemistry which will prepare me for Organic Chemistry II and future more advanced courses.

I learned a lot about the basics of organic chemistry. I learned to predict reaction products, especially reactions of alkyl halides, alkanes, and Alkenes. I learned about stereochemistry. I learned about chirality and stereoisomers. I feel like I left class everyday with a concrete list of information that I had learned that day.
I learned knowledge of organic chemistry.
I developed a better understanding of organic chemistry and gained better problem solving skills.
Really being ablate understand organic chemistry and how to learn it.
Gained a whole new knowledge set of chemistry. An entirely new way of thinking about reactions and chemistry that feels much more "real" and biologically relevant than general chemistry.
Improved the skill of taking book notes and class notes.
I learned basic organic chemistry, especially a lot of very important reactions in the subject.
The fundamentals of organic chemistry.
I learned a lot of stereochemistry and reaction mechanisms.
I developed many, many important skills relating to organic chemistry.
The shape of many molecules and how to draw mechanisms for reactions.
I developed my knowledge of basic organic chemistry reactions and their mechanisms
I developed an understanding of certain concepts in organic chemistry, and I learned how to visualize and draw out organic chemical reactions to better understand them.
I learned about organic chemistry more in depth and the concept of molecules.

I learned about basic organic reactions, writing reaction mechanisms, stereochemistry, different reaction pathways (Sn1/Sn2, E1/E2), and predicting the outcomes of reactions based on the structures and properties of molecules involved in a reaction system.

Professor Ellman is a wonderful instructor and he breaks down some complicated material into digestible bits. Take careful notes and most importantly do problems! There are no problem sets, only book problems, which will really help you if you do them and kind of screw you if you don't.
How to write chemical reactions
I learned a great deal about organic chemistry and how prevalent it is in medicine.

Professor Ellman's teaching style was organized and conducive to learning for those students who put in the time. The exams were very similar to posted practice exams, which made students comfortable with the format going into each test.

However, I heard some T.As were better than others and the TA organized review sessions were kind of awkward and not as well organized.

Ellman organized the class in a great way. I tried highlighting my notes and ended up highlighting everything. He really tells you immediately what you need to know, and it's true to the test. Although there's like one curveball per test, the material and practice tests are all very true to what you can see on an exam.
One strength is the professor's ability to teach the material in the simplest manner possible, then expand on those ideas once we have gotten the basic concept.

Really appreciated the grading system--had anything more been assigned, it would have been too much. Professor Ellman is a phenomenal instructor who explains this (sort of dry) material very clearly. However, it did feel as if the last couple of weeks of the class accelerated through material at a rate much, much faster than earlier in the semester. Maybe that material could be moved earlier in the semester, or truncated.
The set up of the class is great for facilitating student learning. The weakness is that the sections weren't very good. The sections could be improved with more practice problems
Great professor and notes taken during lecture. No weaknesses other than practice is essential for understanding.

The class is well structured and Ellman is a good professor. It feels strange that 80% of the final exam was material covered in the last 2 weeks, especially since it's worth such a large percentage of our final grade.

I really liked the course overall. Weekly problem sets might have helped synthesize the material more, but the quizzes also did a decent job. I thought there were times where we were not sufficiently prepared for certain test questions given what we were presented in class and section.

One of the weaknesses of the class is that a large portion of the grade (45%) is what is covered during the last couple of lectures (material on which you were never assessed). In this sense, it is not very cumulative and your grade largely depends on material that I felt was rushed. The beginning of the semester (all the way through the 3rd midterm) all progressed at a good pace that allowed students to keep up, but then post Midterm #3, many reactions were introduced without much time being spent on them. This quickly became overwhelming and caused me to lose my confidence that I understood the material.

I also believe the course could be improved if the answer keys were posted with more in depth explanations (especially for the multiple choice). It is often difficult to correct your mistakes and learn from assessments since very little feedback is given.

The first 2/3 of this course were taught very clearly at a pace that made sense for student learning, but then right at the end, and exponentially during the last three or four lectures, the material picked up a ton, which was frustrating because I thought I had a good grip on things, and then they got away from me before I knew it. Professor Ellman was always incredibly organized, which helped up until the material itself became very unorganized and disjointed. I think the quizzes and midterms were fair, but the final emphasized the very end of the course and a lot of the material we had never been tested on, which in my opinion, made it so that my performance on the final didn't reflect the work I put in throughout the semester. Still, I think that the course is generally well taught, and if the last few weeks of teaching were ironed out, I wouldn't have any reservations asserting that.

I thought the last couple weeks were very rushed. Also, I wish that we had graded psets, which would keep us more accountable and on top of our work. 

I loved the course overall, however. I never expected to enjoy organic chemistry. The lectures were very helpful and the tests were fair.

Strengths: Professor Ellman is for sure the strength of the course. He, unlike most other professors in STEM here, actually wants his students to master and enjoy the content. He doesn't try to overwhelm the student by teaching too much or too quickly. He hand writes everything on the board for every lecture, in a way that is very clear and at a nice pace. He always makes it very clear what he will be testing, and provides a good outline for reading and doing practice problems in the book. He also provides 3 (!) practice exams for all the midterms and the final, which were invaluable for studying.

Weaknesses: There are no problems sets, which sounds like a weird thing to complain about, but I think the course could really benefit from them. Orgo is something you really only understand and master by doing, and it can be hard sometimes to get that practice at the level expected for the exams.

Ellman is a great lecturer, and the course itself was super interesting. It was A LOT better than Gen Chem, and a lot more interesting. It's great that there are quizzes that keep you on track. The midterms and quizzes aren't super stressful too, because on of them can be dropped. All around organized really well; Ellman really knows what he's doing.
Ellman is a very strong professor. One of the best I have had in three years at yale. Clear presentation of material and very fair assessment.

I believe that course material can be more evenly redistributed throughout the semester. We learned about 20 new reactions and mechanisms in the last 3 weeks of class, whereas we only did a few in September and October. I understand this is because we were learning the things necessary for exploring future reactions, but perhaps a slight redistribution would make finals period less intense for students.
Its just a lot of material in a pretty short amount of time. The course goes by very fast so do your best not to fall behind.

In order to succeed in this class you have to really understand the information, you can't just memorize it which is really good. However, I would have preferred more of the smartwork stuff like in general chemistry so you can see how you're doing and have more practice. Giving us problems out of the book is good but it is a lot of responsibility for the students.
I liked the pace of the course at the beginning. However, it got a little bit overwhelming in the final couple of weeks.

The lectures were clear and easy to follow and the quiz/midterm format was helpful in staying on top of the material. One weakness is that the pacing was slightly uneven; the end of the course from the third midterm to the final contained a lot of material that may have been better introduced earlier. Graded homework assignments would have also been helpful in keeping students accountable and on time with the material (with more of a buffer than the short quizzes) while also helping students by putting more grades in the system.

Strength: This is how a STEM course should be taught. No bullshit lectures that give you exactly the information you need. Optional homework problems where doing them only benefits your understanding but allows you to get to them when you have time. Lots of practice exams that give you an exact feel for how the exams will be and give you an opportunity to truly assess your conceptualization of the topics. Overall a 10/10 course. 

Weaknesses: There could be better posting of the grades... It was a bit annoying to have to go through the secondary step of the TA's.
It was SO SO WELL ORGANIZED. VERY conducive to learning.

Professor Ellman was excellent at explaining all concepts. The structure of lectures was good, however I would like to see a bit more interaction. Additionally, I would like to see students held more accountable for our homework, such as with online quizzes etc. I believe that would help students stay on top of their work and understand concepts a bit better.

I thought the course was very clearly taught and paced well enough that it was easy to follow. It was organized very well. The one weakness is we learned a lot in the last two weeks and the exam was largely on that material and I wish they had spread that out more.
Loved this class. Definitely my favorite course I took this semester.
The class is well-organized. The pace really picks up the last several weeks of classes so don't fall behind.

The strength of this course was that it was very very well organized. All the reading and homework assignments were relevant and helpful. Professor Ellman's lectures were very clear and straightforward, and I liked that he wrote on the chalkboard instead of using a powerpoint. It was very easy to know how to prepare for the exams because Professor Ellman gave us three full practice tests before every exam, which was a wonderful way to study the material. Of all the courses I've taken at Yale, this course was by far the best organized to facilitate student learning.

The weakness of this course is that section was pretty unstructured, so a lot of people decided to skip section because they just saw it as "extra help".

I feel like the spacing of the course material was very unevenslower in the beginning and then at the end, we learned several mechanisms all at once and didnt take the time to learn the differences and similarities. 

Other than that, I thought Ellman was a great Professor. Everything was well explained and the pace in class was appropriate.
I loved this class! I hope it never changes

I think Professor Ellman is a very effective lecturer. He is so clear and organized. He is honestly the best STEM professor I have had at Yale, and I would be surprised if there was anyone better than him. However, I think the class could benefit from having graded problem sets, although this might be too much work for the TFs.
I didn't find lecture particularly helpful. Also, if the course could be weighted less toward the final exam that would reduce the stress level.
Honestly this course was amazing. I felt that the practice tests and assigned problems really prepared me well for the tests.

The professor was incredibly organized, so his lecture notes were always helpful. Hes also incredibly engaging, so going to his lectures was always a pleasure (despite the 9:25 time!) 

I think we spent most of the class just learning about organic chemistry with very little context. The professor occasionally mentioned applications of specific synthesis reactions, especially in medicine, but I wish there was more of that stuff. I also think that a lot of the assigned problems were actually irrelevant to the course. There was a huge number of practice problems available, and its good to have the extra practice, but most of the questions were a lot harder than what we were expected to know for the exams. I feel like I spent a lot of time working on the problems, and I got to the exam and really felt like doing the problems wasnt exactly a good use of my time.
Ellman is a great teacher, the course teaches a lot of intuition, which is beneficial to any potential chemists.

This course teaches a lot of organic chemistry topics in a short amount of time. My biggest issue with the course was that the material near the end of the semester was so unbelievably rushed and difficult to understand, and then our final exam was almost entirely on topics taught in the last week and a half of class.

Prof. Ellman is a great lecturer, and the low workload is a plus, but I would love to have a little dilution of my grade in terms of some homeworks perhaps. Also hard to predict my grade with little feedback.

I have nothing to complain about with this course. The material was taught in an incredibly clear and understandable way. I felt like Professor Ellman genuinely cared about students and wanted us to do well.
It's a really tough course but there is a lot of help available

Prof. Ellman  is a very clear teacher and write some out everything you need to know on the board and thats good for the asking notes (he writes too small sometimes), and the notes are not bad to take. There are only 2 midterms and a final that count, and 3 quizzes that count (which are a small percentage) so theres no homework to count or p-sets like gen chem. So it might be difficult to have a lot of chances to bring a grade up.

Strengths: the textbook, Professor Ellman is a great lecturer, the pace, the practice tests

Weaknesses: it seemed like we jammed in a bunch of reactions at the end

The weakness of this course is the class size; with hundreds of students, there is nobody to help one-on-one, and so the students' must be responsible for their own work. Additionally, I don't feel like the lectures were helpful in learning the material, as they were fairly different than what was tested on the exams. Nonetheless, the material and course were interesting and engaging.

It was straightforward and well taught (albeit quite difficult, especially if you get behind) but felt totally irrelevant. I know the applications for organic chemistry are enormous, I just wish this course included them!!

This was an excellent curse! Probably one of the best taught science courses I have taken so far. Professor Ellman gives clear and concise notes which are easy to understand and highlight all of the essential material that one needs to know. Quizzes reinforce this knowledge by asking textbook questions. For exams professor Ellman posts 3 practice tests which all have the same format and style as the real test and are excellent practice. This course was excellent and I don't know how an organic chemistry course can be better taught.
A strength is that the lectures are easy to follow and the teaching staff is very helpful.
The only way to earn grades is from exams rather than also being graded on participation/problem sets.
The exams are each after a break which is not ideal, also i wish there were psets or homeworks
The lectures were VERY effective at summarizing the material of the text, but because of the pace of the course, there weren't opportunities to ask questions during lecture
Not really any weaknesses. If you put in the work that you should, its fine. Very good teacher. Online notes from class would be helpful.

I really liked the material and the professor and how prepared we were for the midterms, but a lot of the reactions and their mechanisms seemed squished into the last two weeks of classes, making it hard to get a proper understanding of them right before the final. The information could have been spread out a little more!
This course overall is pretty much as good of an organic chemistry class as you will get.
Nicely organized, final worth way too much

The course is well taught by Professor Ellman, and the TA's are all very good. One weakness would be the amount of material that gets covered in the last two weeks, and having three midterms, which makes it feel like your are never done preparing for tests.

I dont think the test format is very fair because it is very easy to lose lots of point so on small multiple choice mistakes which count for almost as much as complicated mechanisms. Its also completely memorization and I think there should be more conceptual parts.
A very straightforward course, perhaps the most straightforward course I have ever encountered at Yale. Can't think of any particular weaknesses.
PSETS would have been helpful. Homework did not reflect ourselves content.
You go through the material very quickly, if you do not keep up with readings you will fall behind fast.
Awesome professor, not a ton of work outside of midterms and the final

The pace of the course accelerated incredibly quickly after the third midterm and before the final, so much so that a lot of the learning had to be done on one's own instead of in lecture. Plus, the material learned at the end was the most challenging and was essentially the summation of everything that had lead up to it, so I wish more time had been spent talking through some of the important alcohol/ether/epoxide reactions rather than quickly presenting them and skipping onto the next reaction.

It might be helpful to introduce a slice of the final grade as homework, since currently a lot of the book problems go untouched week-to-week and students seem mainly to use them to study for quizzes/exams instead of regularly doing them, which I think would be valuable.
The course is well organized. There are no graded assigned psets, so it was on the student to practice problems from the textbook to learn.

Definitely hard subject matter. Wish there were other resources given to us in class aside from on board. I did not like that each midterm followed a break which meant that I didnt really have those breaks.
Th course was very well organized and taught in a clear manner.

I thought the course was very well taught and there was a good logic behind it. Honestly it would probably have helped me a bit if the homeworks were checked, even just for completion, although I know that in theory that shouldn't affect my motivation to do them...

I am a fan of the no PSET, three exam system with 4 quizzes that make sure you stay on top of everything without the consistent hassle of a weekly pset. Additionally, you get to drop both a quiz and one of the exams. The one weakness is that the material at the end felt very rushed and was not as clearly explained as the rest of the course.
very well taught, lectures are easy to follow

Strengths - very organized, Prof Ellman gives very comprehensive notes during lecture, curved generously 
Weakness - he taught us too much material in the last two days of class

Ellman is a fantastic professor. he teaches the course very well. I would say the biggest weakness of the course is that the last 3 weeks is crammed full of new material that really should be spaced out over a longer period of time (especially since that was what almost the entire final was over). Otherwise the course was great.
Well organized and well taught, but too much material so felt rushed on some concepts

The content is very well taught, and the lectures were very organized. CHEM 220 lectures had been much easier to follow than the gen chem lectures. Prof. Ellman is very talented at presenting information and explaining the principles behind reactions.

The last two weeks felt very rushed because we were given so many reactions in a very compressed amount of time. I think perhaps pacing could be done better.

Also, it was scary that the entire grade depended solely on quizzes and exams. Perhaps homework could count as ~10% of the grade, to motivate students to do them in a timely manner, and to reduce a little bit of stress.

Lectures were very well organized and material was taught in a logical manner.  The last two weeks of class were a little too fast and I would have preferred that the first two thirds of the class were taught faster so that there would be more time for the last third.

This course was wonderful. Professor Ellman structured it in a way that was easy to follow and was fairly paced. In the beginning we spent a lot of time on the basics, which was important to build a strong foundation so that near the end when we were learning mechanisms all of it was fathomable. Near the end though, it did become a little difficult as there were so many mechanisms to memorize, but I don't think it could have been done any other way. Overall great course.

I felt that the course was well structured and taught very clearly by the instructor, which I personally think is very important for learning organic chemistry. However, the material was very rushed towards the end, when we covered about 3 chapters in several days, which was both unexpected and more difficult to digest.

The course gives detailed information about the topics we cover and explanations are given for every established rule. One weakness was that in the last week and a half of class too much information was covered. A lot of reactions were given to us back to back and it became hard to keep up with the material.

The lectures were well done but very fast and covered a great deal of material (which was to be expected). Toward the end of the semester, material was a bit jumbled and difficult to process, but that's my only real complaint.
I think the class started too slow, but finished too fast. A huge amount of material was covered in the last two weeks, and that made up most of the final exam (which is 45% of your grade).

Professor Ellman is a great professor, and the material covered in class follows a logical order and is interesting. The last two weeks did feel very crammed, as we learned a lot more reactions than in the entire rest of the semester. Spacing it out would have helped me better digest material and prepare for the exam. Also, having the entire class grade based only on exam scores was a little nerve-wracking, and while it doesn't have to be changed, I think that adding more homework scores would have helped people feel more confident about their work in the class.

AMAZING CLASS, by far the best-taught STEM lecture I have ever taken. Both the readings and lectures were extremely helpful, and the tests were reasonable and a good assessment of your understanding. I could not have asked for a better-taught organic chemistry class.
The course was very well organized, but at the end of the class, we went through the material very fast.

I think a strength of this class is its organization. Prof. Ellman is very organized and has a clear plan for each day. I think this especially helps when we are learning a difficult topic. Another strength of this course is that there are no mandatory psets, so students are free to spend more or less time on this class as their schedule allows. I think a weakness of this course is its overall pacingin the last week, we learned about fifteen to twenty different reactions that we were expecting to know fully for the final exam. On the other hand, the first two weeks of the class were a bit slow (although this was appreciated, adjusting to a new semester). I think slightly modifying the pacing of the class so the last few days were a bit slower would be better.
All of the difficult stuff was crammed into the last two weeks and completely overwhelmed me.
Great professor, taught very well and even though the material is difficult, it is not too difficult to understand.

It's good that you can drop one midterm because it allows for mistakes. However, I felt like the grading or point distributions on the tests were kind of harsh. Also, I did not like the distribution of grading in general, in which 45% of the grade was the final and there were no problem sets.
There were no problem sets that were required, which I think may have been useful. Other than that, this course was very well structured I think!

This class is extremely well taught for a large survey/lecture course.  It is so smart that the professor writes the notes with us on the board. I only wish he stopped for questions more frequently or encouraged more questions during class.

Strengths: Professor Ellman is an amazing lecturer. His explanations of the course content and what we were expected to know for the exams were clear. In addition, I believed that having the quizzes throughout the course was a great way to make sure that we are keeping up with the course content. The practice exams really helped in studying for the midterms and final.

Weakness: None

The strengths of this course are that the lectures were very organized and structured in a way that was easy to understand and learn. However, the grade was entirely based on tests and quizzes so you had to make sure you did well on every test. Also, many of the TAs were not very good and did not know how to teach very well. A strength is that Professor Ellman was very helpful and willing to answer all your questions.
strengths: The professor. He was amazing. The course was well designed and well taught. Other than the fact that it was organic chemistry there were no weaknesses.

We definitely rushed at the end, and it was really hard catching up. Otherwise, the course was very well structured. I wish we had more problem sets from Professor Ellman instead of book problems though, just to make sure everyone was on the same page.
In my opinion, the course was very well-structured in the beginning, but sort of fell apart at the end due to the amount of material that was needed to be covered.

The textbook is EXCELLENT, the most useful I've had in any class outside of foreign language. Lectures also follow the textbook very closely. There are no weekly problem sets which can be an advantage or disadvantage depending on how apt you are to keep up with the material.
Lecture notes were great and really liked the book problems being listed in order to practice what was learned.

I think the beginning of the class was really timed, it was slow enough to let students really understand the subject. However, there was a lot of material stuffed into the last 2 weeks of class and it was very overwhelming for the final exam.
Professor is great. Practice exams are very helpful. Towards the end of the semester, make sure to stay caught up with the material.

Well organized lectures, very fair exams and quizzes. It was very helpful that you could drop a quiz and an exam. The fact that the homework problems were not graded was very unfortunate, though, and made it hard to motivate yourself to keep up with the material.

The lectures are very organized but I don't think the lectures cover everything tested in the test. Or a better way of putting it, the lectures don't teach you how to approach the questions on the test.
I think weekly problem sets would be beneficial for some, and hurtful to others. Maybe short, weekly problem sets would be helpful.
The strengths are not having problem sets. The weakness was having the final exam focusing on the last chapter which we barely covered in class and was in the last few weeks of term.
The course went pretty slowly during the first half and then sped up a lot near the end; distributing the pace more evenly might have been good.

This course was very clear and mostly very well structured. Towards the end, it felt as if the material was rushed through a little bit, but overall the pace of the course was good. Not having any homework to be submitted was nice, but you need to make sure to stay on top of the problems and reading yourself. It also could have been nice to have homework be a portion of the overall grade so the final and midterms didn't count for as much.

The main weakness of the course is that unfortunately, individual experience and in depth understanding is highly dependent on the TAs; while several were fantastic, a few were not and it felt 'unfair' to be at this kind of disadvantage.  The lectures themselves were generally great and easy to follow; although at times there were concepts that were less clear and explanations in the book were not terribly helpful.

strengths: My section was well taught with a TA who showed genuine concern for my learning and performance. The class itself was well taught, with clear handwriting and an adequate pace. 

Weaknesses: The flow of ideas was not always apparent, leaving me to retroactively piece together why i had learned a given fact. Another weakness is the communication of to what degree I should concern myself with mechanisms. The last questions wherein I was required to show mechanisms of how to get a product from a given reactant were where this lack of clarity proved most costly.
The course material was organized fairly well, but I think it would have been helpful if there were problem sets or some type of homework assignments.

This course is taught in a very organized way. Professor Ellman is very clear on the board, and the curriculum follows the textbook very closely. I think it moves very fast, but this is a challenge and not a deficit, because there just a lot of material to cover. I wish there were problem sets in addition to the book problems. I think turning in a weekly problem set would help me be more accountable for the material, even though I think we should have the discipline to do problems ourselves.
The sections were very helpful and provided an opportunity to ask questions that arise during lecture.

The lectures are well-organized and relatively clear. However, I often found myself having to decide between either drawing all of the reactions properly or listening to his commentary on each reaction and why each step occurs like it does. Also, some basic information is not covered at all in the course, such as the different functional groups. While I understand not taking class time to discuss these, it would have been nice to know when we were responsible for this information. Also, a more detailed structure for the course would have been nice. While I understand the random nature of the quizzes, it would have been nice to know the homework assignments earlier than just the class period before they are due, as it made it difficult to get ahead on readings and assignments when I knew I had something coming up.

I loved the content of this course, but it is fair to say it is not necessarily a must-take if you have no interest in pursuing science or a career field in which organic chemistry is required. If you have a reason to take this course, definitely do.
Has to be taken for pre-med requirements, but if you put the work in, it makes sense and is rewarding. I recommend it, and you'll learn more about chemistry in a broader sense.
I wouldn't take the class unless you have to.

I think it is a good intro to orgo class in terms of mechanisms. I know lots of people are taking it as a requirement (myself included) and though we learn a lot of interesting things, I do agree that it is A LOT of work to get though the class, especially if it is not a requirement.
Orgo can seem scary but if you go to lecture and stay engaged you can learn.
Would recommend. Love Professor Ellman.
Yes I would!
Chances are you kinda have to take it, but it's pretty good with Ellman.
Yes this is an effective intro to organic chemistry.

If you are taking this course it is likely because you need to, for premed or your major. I was in that same but, but I actually really enjoyed orgo, and most of that was due to Ellman. He is a wonderful professor--very clear, fair, and organized--and made learning the material so much easier!
Decent class that gets a bad rap, but is actually more enjoyable than general chemistry.

Not really a choice a lot of people have. I liked taking this with Professor Ellman even though I had the option to do it on the off-sequence. Being in a large lecture comes with its setbacks, but on the whole, I appreciated the way this course was taught. It's such a blessing to be able to drop a quiz and a midterm. Really pay attention the last two weeks of classes.
Don't be afraid of this course! I thought I would fail but I actually ended up enjoying it!

Nobody really has the choice to take Orgo 1, I think. However, even if I had the choice, I would have taken this course again. It was really refreshing to have taken a course where the professor actually teaches and clearly wants his students to do well. Also, I found the content to be really interesting and relevant.
Yes; do it even just for fun if you're interested in Chemistry. I doubt that anybody would though; but people who must take the class: do not fear, it's great.

I would recommend this course to other students, but I also understand that many students will end up taking this course mainly to satisfy requirements (pre-med). I thought overall it was a very well taught course. Professor Ellman is a very good lecturer, so actually coming to class is helpful. Before each lecture, there were readings from the textbook that students were assigned to read before coming in, just to have some understanding. I personally thought the textbook was very dry and hard to understand, so to resolve that I just reviewed the topics of each lecture after class using the Organic Chemistry as a second language textbook, which was very easy to understand and kind of entertaining. 
Bottom line: You are probably taking this class because you have to- so just make it bearable, stay on top of the material to do well on the exams.
Yes. Great class even though it is something everyone must take.
Only if you need to take it, or have an affinity for complicated reaction mechanisms.
I would only take it if you have to because it's pretty difficult.
Yes if you're premed, it's challenging but rewarding
Yes, I thought this course gave an excellent introduction to organic chemistry.
The course was clear enough and fairly manageable. Professor Ellman is a good lecturer and there are many opportunities to do well.
i mean if you gotta take it, you gotta take it, but its definitely not a bad class to take
If you gotta you gotta. But this course isn't that bad.

100%. Ellman is a brilliant person but that does not cloud his ability to teach, unlike many professors at this school. He is SUPER clear, makes everything as straightforward as possible, and covers everything you need to know in lecture. The quizzes are often an L but they're only worth a small percentage of your grade, and in the end are super helpful for keeping everyone caught up on the information throughout the course.

If you need to take OChem for pre med, or for your major, do it. There's no way around that. But, unless you are REALLY interested in Chemistry, this course is most likely too difficult and too much work to take otherwise.

I mean people generally take this course because they have to and I'm not sure I would have taken it if I wasn't pre-med but it was one of the best pre-med courses I've taken. Very interesting and I learned a lot.
Yes this is a good course if you are interested in understanding fundamentals of carbon chemistr.
Yes. Great class that I would highly recommend.

I loved Organic Chemistry, even though I took it as just a required class. Professor Ellman is really phenomenal, and the pace is fast enough to stay challenging but never overwhelming. The course is designed for students who can stay on top of their own work, and I liked that we didn't have to hand in problem sets.

This course is extremely well-organized, really interesting, and Ellman is a PHENOMENAL professor. As long as you put in the work on learning the really straightforward material, you'll be fine. There are no surprises in this course, no tricks on the exams. There's a LOT of material though, which is why it takes up a lot of time. Otherwise, I really enjoyed it.
Do the problemseven though they arent required, they really help you learn. Also keep track of the reactions and mechanisms as you go through the class.
Absolutely! This class is one of if not the best class Ive taken at Yale, and I would recommend it to anyone
Only would recommend this course to a science major.
If you need it for your major or for prereqs, take it. Otherwise, I don't think this is a fun subject.
Only take it if you have to.
Yes I would, I quite enjoyed the class and thought it thought provoking and fun.

I definitely recommend this class to other students. Im usually really unhappy with the course selection for the biology majors because there are so many prerequisites, all of which are necessary but also not particularly interesting, but this was the first course in my major that I was actually excited about. Professor Ellman is a fantastic lecturer: organized, engaging, and incredibly helpful. I found myself incredibly excited to go to lecture just to see how hes going to present the material.
Yes, it's a great course.
YES!
If you need orgo, this is a great class to take (even if you're a freshman! So much better than freshman orgo).

If you are going to take orgo anywhere in the country, please, please take it with Professor Ellman. I can't emphasize enough how incredible this class was. Also, please go to office hours with him - it is so helpful!
Only if you have to take it

If you need this for a pre-req or pre-med than go for it. You kind of dont have a choice, but if you dont need it, then dont worry  about it. But Prof. Ellman is nice to work with and teaches clearly and wel  so if you really do want to learn about o-chem, then it might be worth it.
Yes!
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs it for their major or has a specific interest in organic chemistry.
Probably shouldn't take this unless you really have to.
Yes for any stem student planning to take orgo, take it with Professor Ellman.
definitely not unless it is a requirement
Yes. Its a very important branch of science that everyone should be familiar with.
Yes!! Orgo is super fun!!! (Just also super hard.)

Totally. Professor Ellman is amazing. He will make organic chemistry interesting and manageable. His practice exams are amazing, and he is organized beyond belief. His lecture notes are so clear and he writes everything down.
Only for any requirements
If you have to take orgo, definitely take it with prof. Ellman.
I dont have super strong feelings one way or another.
Yes!
Great professor
Its one of those classes you need for a major or for premed
If you're interested in organic chemistry the course is really good and well-organized. One of the most clear lecture classes I have taken, so you will definitely learn a lot by the end.
Only if required by major or premed.
I think that if a student needs to take organic chemistry, this is the class for them.

I thought that this semester of orgo was very well taught and well organized. I was just taking it for fun, I'm not premed and its not a major requirement or anything but honestly I did learn a lot and I think it will be helpful in my research on microbial anaerobic metabolic pathways.

You are probably taking this course because you have to. If you are deciding whether or not you want to pursue an area of study involving taking orgo or not, I wouldn't let this class deter you. It's not as bad as the rep it gets.
Loved this class!
Yes-- very organized and rewards those who study

Yes, please take it. Ellman was an amazing professor. The content is really well taught. Be warned: the tests get consecutively harder and don't let the grading fool you. Even though the class is on a heavy curve, you really need to study for the exams and quizzes. This is not a class you can just blow off and hope to do well. The final is one of the hardest tests I've taken here at Yale. You need to be organized and on top of things to do well in this course, but, otherwise, you will turn out fine.
Good and necessary for building organic chemistry foundation

If you have taken gen chem, might as well take orgo! It's actually a lot of fun. A lot of people hear nightmare stories about orgo (especially at other schools), but CHEM 220 is very very well taught. The competition is pretty high indeed, due to high number of premed students. But if you focus on learning the material and do the homework in a timely manner, you won't have too much of a problem.

The ability to visualize 3D structures in your head is very important for this class. If you have taken MATH 120, then you probably won't have much problem. But if you know that you have challenges in this area, then you might want to get a model and dedicate extra time.

Ellman is a great professor for the first semester of orgothe lectures follow the textbook extremely well and the tests are fairvery similar to the practice exams. There are no problem sets so its up to you to keep up with material.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Ellman is one of the best professors I've ever had and the material learned here was pretty interesting.

I think this is a wonderful course to take if you are interested because it covers a good range of organic chemistry without getting too complicated. Then again, it is a requirement for most STEM and pre-meds, so I also recommend it in the sense that it is a requirement.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It was well taught and it provides a basic understanding for organic chemistry. It's also very well taught.
Yes, if you like thinking about chemistry and reaction patterns. Not a gut. Not for humanities students. If you're pre-med, there's no choice really, so good luck!
I would if you like Chemistry.
You probably have to take this class, and Ellman is very solid and clear. However, it will be challenging at the end and I felt I had to learn a lot of material independently.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the material. Professor Ellman is great, and the class is quite doable in terms of workload and in following the material.

This is a FANTASTIC organic chemistry class. Prof Ellman is an amazing lecturer, by far the best teacher out of all of the STEM lectures that I've taken at Yale. The lecture are clear and make a lot of sense, and the readings are extremely helpful at solidifying understanding (though probably not necessary to do well in the class). The class is structured so there are no psets due, but the optional practice problems are extremely helpful and I would absolutely recommend doing them before exams. The quizzes and exams are reasonable, and Ellman always gives us practice exams in advance. Section can also be very helpful, depending on your TF. As long as you keep up with the material you will get a lot out of and do well in this class.
if you have to take it, yes. However, it is a challenging class with a lot of material.

I would recommend this course to another student. Prof. Ellman is fantastic, and really cares about his students. The class overall did not feel too daunting, especially considering that the reputation of organic chemistry precedes it. The material was challenging but generally doable. I would recommend doing the assigned problems, even though they are not turned it, because it helps you stay on top of the lecture material. I would also recommend not skipping class, especially for the last two weeks, when a good amount of material is packed in.
Only if you have to otherwise hell no.
Only take this if you need it for requirements or it will greatly improve the knowledge needed for a specific career youre going into.
yes. it is very informative. very well taught.
Yes, this course was challenging but made me learn in new ways and overcome obstacles.
Yes. It is very organized and the professor is great. Only take if you are interested in orgo.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Ellman is an amazing professor and made learning organic chemistry very enjoyable. The practice exams were very helpful in studying for the midterms and finals.
I would only recommend this course to others if they have to take it. The professor was really nice and helpful. However, the material was very difficult and at times very hard to understand.
100% If you are going to take organic chemistry TAKE THIS CLASS.
It's organic chemistry. There is a lot of memorization and gradations that require a lot of work outside of class to master.
Yes, but only if you're taking this class for your major or if you're a pre-med student.
Yes, but only if you are pre-med
Absolutely. I found it very engaging and interesting.
Take it - but plan the rest of your schedule accordingly because you want to make sure you give this course the time it needs!
Yes. If you are taking this, it is probably for your major anyway, but I learned a lot.

This class is definitely one of the more tolerable pre-med req courses or pre-req stem major courses. It went much better than expected and was manageable through out most of the semester and only got really bad towards the end.
Yes, if you are interested in the subject!

Yes, this course is very well taught and you learn a lot. The grading and exams are very fair and you never feel blindsided. Absolutely take this course with Ellman. He's such a good lecturer and easy to understand. Keep up with the book problems! I didn't do this and I wish I had; I think it really negatively impacted my final grade.
Yes, I would recommend the class. Overall, it's a pretty good class where you learn a lot but the workload isn't overwhelming.

Yes I would recommend this course to another student, because it is an important class to take, particularly for those going into the life sciences. You will develop many important skills necessary for those disciplines.
Yes, especially if you need to take it, it is quite rewarding.
yes because it provides a good base in organic chemistry
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs to take it or anyone who is really interested in organic chemistry. Definitely try to take it with Professor Ellman.

There are no homework grades, but keep in mind that this means all of your grades are from assessments in the form of quizzes/exams, and these are pretty hard. Your experience will depend heavily on which TA you have, so if you feel yours isn't working out I would recommend starting to attend a different TAs section as soon as possible (or even go to more than one section). I probably would have understood the concepts better and performed better if I had done this early on instead of waiting. Professor Ellman is really great though and is very helpful in his office hours and right after class if you have concerns or trouble with concepts.
If you have to take it, take it. if you don't, I do not think there is a clear enough connection between theory and praxis for this course to be of any use. It is clearly an intermediary.
I would only recommend this class to a student if it is a requirement.
This course was very well structured and organized.

I would recommend this course to students interested in chemistry and organic chemistry. It is very organized, clear, and well-taught, which makes some very difficult concepts seem relatively simple to understand. But be prepared to do a lot of problems and have the self-discipline to study something multiple times.
Yes to those interested in organic chemistry
I thought it was interesting and the professor was really good, but most people take this class because they have to.

I believe this course would be great for a student with some prior knowledge of the material, as trying to learn everything from scratch was very time-consuming and made it difficult to keep up with the pace of the class. Also, there is a lot of information that must be memorized, and I personally would have enjoyed learning a lot more about the logics and applications of such information instead of just having to memorize reactions.
